awd_titl_txt: NeTS: Small: Intelligent Optical Networks using Virtualization and Software-Defined Control
awd_abstract_narration:
Software-defined networking (SDN) is a promising paradigm that has the potential to enable Internet Service Providers (ISPs) to achieve a high level of network automation and therefore significant cost savings. Indeed software-defined wide area networks (SD-WANs) are emerging in industry and are projected to account for 25 percent of WAN traffic by 2021.  However, many challenges remain. The networks of large ISPs such as AT&T are complex, and most Internet traffic traverses multiple network domains.  It is highly desirable, then, to extend the software control paradigm to enable fast, efficient, cost effective end-to-end provisioning of services and resources over heterogeneous, multi-domain networks in an integrated and unified way.  The goal of this project is to address research challenges in this area, leveraging SDN and investigating novel strategies for expediting efficient data transfer across the fiber optic backbone networks underlying the Internet.  

A unified network architecture for a software defined optical network (SDON) will be developed that features: (1) End-to-end provisioning of services, and (2) Expediting data transfers over multiple domains that use heterogeneous transport layer technologies using inter-domain tunnels. SDONs will usher in virtualization and intelligence as the new features of future networks. The project will explore different strategies for dynamic resource allocation including the creation and use of virtual transport links (VTL) and associated bandwidth-on-demand (BoD) techniques. The project will also explore a Resource Delayed Release (RDR) strategy to reduce the dynamic service provisioning time and multi-domain tunnels to expedite data transfers in multi-layer networks involving Optical Transport Network (OTN), Wavelength Division Multiplexing (WDM) and Elastic Optical Networking (EON) layers.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Software-defined networking (SDN) is a promising paradigm that has the potential to enable Internet Service Providers (ISPs) to achieve a high level of network automation and therefore significant cost savings. The goal of this project was to address research challenges in the area of Software-Defined Optical Networking, leveraging Software Defined Networking (SDN) and virtualization to investigate novel strategies for expediting efficient data transfer across the fiber optic networks underlying the Internet. Specifically, the project explored different strategies for dynamic resource allocation including the creation and use of virtual transport links (VTL) and associated bandwidth-on-demand (BoD) techniques. The project also explored a Resource Delayed Release (RDR) strategy to reduce the dynamic service provisioning time and multi-domain tunnels to expedite data transfers in multi-layer networks involving Optical Transport Network (OTN), Wavelength Division Multiplexing (WDM) and Elastic Optical Networking (EON) layers. Finally, the project also investigated the integration of physical layer modeling in the simulation of dynamic WDM optical networks.

Intellectual Merit: We proposed a novel strategy called Resource Delayed Release (RDR) to reduce Service Provisioning Time (SPT) and Blocking Probability (BP) in optical networks. The key insight behind RDR is to delay the release of an optical channel when the channel does not carry any services. We showed that the delay in the removal of an idle optical channel helps the next service request to be carried immediately. We also investigated how uniform and non-uniform traffic load influences the SPT, BP as well as Bandwidth Blocking Probability (BBP) and recovery time (RT) of RDR in optical networks. Improving dynamic service provisioning significantly increases the network efficiency. Network availability is an important requirement in an optical telecommunication network. To overcome a disconnection, preparing a backup path before failure happens is required to reroute the affected traffic. This prevents any failure causing a significant amount of data loss or interruption in optical networks. We addressed the problem of single link failure in WDM networks by comparing different protection methods when applied to the RDR strategy. We investigated and compared three algorithms that are mostly intended for maximization of the amount of remaining bandwidth over a damaged network. We also investigated how to improve optimized multilayer optical routing systems with service mesh performance costs to improve end-to-end service performance. We also investigated different machine learning techniques and their application in optical networks, working on protection algorithms and routing and spectrum allocation problems in elastic optical networks using deep reinforcement learning. Lastly, we incorporated physical layer models for Direct Optical Networks (DONs) and Coherent Optical Networks (CONs) in optical network simulators.

Broader Impacts: Graduate students were trained in the topics of high-speed networks, optical networking, software-defined networking, network security, and network design. The project results were incorporated into the Optical Communication Networks course taught at the University of Nebraska-Lincoln. Undergraduate students were involved in the project through an REU supplement to the project award. An international collaboration with the Indian Institute of Technology-Madras (IIT-M) was established through another supplement to the project award. The project results were disseminated widely through peer-reviewed conference and journal publications, PhD dissertations and technical reports.
